review.title: Enriching Linked Datasets with New Object Properties
review.abstract: Although several RDF knowledge bases are available through the LOD initiative, often these data sources remain isolated, lacking schemata and links to other datasets. While there are numerous works that focus on establishing that two resources are identical and on adding more instances of an already existing relation, the problem of finding new relations between any two given datasets has not been investigated in detail. In this paper, given two entity sets, we present an unsupervised approach to enrich the LOD cloud with new relations between them by exploiting the web corpus. During the first phase we gather prospective relations from the corpus through pattern extraction and paraphrase detection. In the second phase, we perform actual enrichment by extracting instances of these relations. We have empirically evaluated our approach on several dataset pairs and found that the system can indeed be used for enriching the existing datasets with new relations.

metadata.title: Enriching Linked Datasets with New Object Properties

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 6.07 572v 3 [cs.D B] 4S ep2 017Although several RDF knowledge bases are available through the LOD initiative, the ontology scheme of such linked datasets is not very rich. In particular, they lack object properties. The problem of finding new object properties (and their instances) between two given classes has not been studied in detail in the context of linked data. In this paper, we present DART (Detecting ArbitraryRelations for enriching T-Boxes of Linked Data) - an unattended solution to enrich the LOD cloud with new object properties between two given classes. DART uses the contextual similarity to identify text patterns from the web corpus that can potentially represent relationships between individuals. These text patterns are then clustered using paraphrase recognition to capture the objects between the two given classes LOD.

sections.heading: 3.1 Pre-processing
sections.text: Given two classes D1 and D2, we need patterns that occur in the web corpus along with instances D1 and D2 to discover the possible relationships between them. Therefore, for this purpose, we obtain triples (subject, predicate, object) - known as triple corpus C from RCE 1.1 file 8, so that subject and object belong to D1 (D2) and D2 (D1) respectively. We have used the RCE dataset in our experiments because newOntExt uses ReVerb and we wanted to maintain a uniform set of inputs for both DART and newOntExt for fair comparison. However, we can also replace this step in the following ways: use a web corpus like ClueWeb and extract sentences containing instances of D1 and D2; then use any triplication tool such as ClausIE [8], Ollie [21], etc., to obtain the input corpus.

sections.heading: 3.3 Grounding of relations
sections.text: Once the discovery phase of the relationship generates relationships between the two input classes, the system must check whether these relationships can be established in the linked dataset, i.e. whether they can be mapped to an existing property in the linked dataset. Only when a relationship cannot be grounded (mapped to existing LOD properties) is it added as a new relationship, leading to a T-box enrichment of the linked dataset. To establish a representative relationship to existing LOD properties, DART checks the semantic similarity between a LOD property p and the representative relationship r (using Equation (2), but with an increased threshold of 0.75, as we want to avoid false mappings).

sections.heading: 3.4 Triple finding phase
sections.text: At this stage, we intend to find all triples (s, p, o) where p is a relationship found in the previous phase, thus enriching the A-box of the linked dataset. To obtain the instances of a new relationship (let's call this "p"), each relationship "r" in the p cluster in corpus C is searched for, and the subject-object pair found in C is given for the relationship "r" as an instance of "p." This (subject, p, object) becomes the last triple. Note here that the relationship ("r") sought in the corpus has a forward direction, and the relationship "p" has a reverse direction (conception of directions explained in Section 3.1), then the final threefold is given as output (object, p, subject).

sections.heading: 4 EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS
sections.text: The proposed system, DART, was implemented in Java 1.7, and all the experiments were carried out on a Linux system equipped with an Intel 3.20 GHz quad-core processor and 32 GB of RAM. Full details of the input classes, relationships and relationship instances achieved can be found on our project page 11. The experiments carried out on the NELL Knowledge Base for the purpose of comparing DART with newOntExt, and the observations made, are listed in Section 4.1. Details of the experiments carried out to measure the performance of DART in LOD classes are listed in Section 4.2.

sections.heading: 4.2 Evaluation of DART on linked datasets
sections.text: In this section, we will present a report on the experiments to demonstrate the enrichment of LOD by DART, i.e. we have chosen classes from linked data sets such as YAGO and DBpedia as our entry classes. Table 4 gives the details of the entry classes obtained by DART. We have selected these classes from different areas (geography, literature, history and music) to prove that our approach is multi-faceted. Table 5 gives a report on the few ownership relationships in each experiment, and the measures that DART has taken based on the relationships it has established. The full list of relations generated is available in our project. Table 6 shows the accuracy and number of obtained ownership relationships in the entry classes.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTUREWORK
sections.text: The central idea behind this paper is to propose a fully automated and unsupervised technique for identifying possible arbitrary relationships between two classes of linked data. To this end, we have developed a system, DART, whose functioning combines contextual similarity checking and paraphrase recognition techniques into a unified framework for discovering new relationships from web patterns. DART then attempts to ground the discovered relationships in the linked data set to discard irrelevant relationships and identify new relationships. The fully automated grounding method proposed in this paper also generates future property axioms for enriching the linked data sets. The results collected reveal the potential of DART to uncover many interesting relationships between a given class pair, leading to the growth of a relationship-rich LOD. DART surpasses the state-of-the-art system in terms of validity and number of relationships. As part of our future work, we intend to improve the exploration validation and validation methods for their validation.

In [22], the individual word-to-word similarity valueswere weighted using a word specificity measure so that higher importance can be given to a semantic matching identified between two specific words such as “collie" and “sheepdog" when compared to a matching identified between words such as “get" and “become".
ing a low weight to such words (as done in [22]) is not appropriate in the context of DART.
5 (adopted from [22]).
LESK [3] has been used to perform the word-to-word similarity component of equation (2), as it works for all combinations of parts of speech.

Note that there are a few other works in the literature (such as [10]) which focus mainly on the grounding of relations in a Knowledge Base (KB).
Moreover in systems such as [10], grounding of relations is based on the grounding of entities.
Also, the method in [10] is semi-automatic i.
We have used the implementation of newOntExt provided by the authors of [4]13.

Since the value of k used is not mentioned in ([4], [5]) and has been fixed in a dataset-specific manner in [25], we have applied the Elbow method [34] to determine the best k value (from a range of k=3 to k=29) for clustering the patterns, for each experiment.

These property axioms can further be validated through techniques that are based on determining the support from the instances [12] and then added to the T-Box.
DART has not been compared with any of the property alignment systems (such as those surveyed in [14]) since the main goal of DART is to gener-

metadata.abstractText: Although several RDF knowledge bases are available through the LOD initiative, the ontology schema of such linked datasets is not very rich. In particular, they lack object properties. The problem of finding new object properties (and their instances) between any two given classes has not been investigated in detail in the context of Linked Data. In this paper, we present DART (Detecting ArbitraryRelations for enriching T-Boxes of Linked Data) an unsupervised solution to enrich the LOD cloud with new object properties between two given classes. DART exploits contextual similarity to identify text patterns from the web corpus that can potentially represent relations between individuals. These text patterns are then clustered by means of paraphrase detection to capture the object properties between the two given LOD classes. DART also performs fully automated mapping of the discovered relations to the properties in the linked dataset. This serves many purposes such as identification of completely new relations, elimination of irrelevant relations, and generation of prospective property axioms. We have empirically evaluated our approach on several pairs of classes and found that the system can indeed be used for enriching the linked datasets with new object properties and their instances. We compared DART with newOntExt system which is an offshoot of the NELL (Never-Ending Language Learning) effort. Our experiments reveal that DART gives better results than newOntExt with respect to both the correctness, as well as the number of relations.
